epidemiology: Most common chronic disease globally; affects ~30% of adults. Risk increases with age, obesity, and family history.
treatment_protocol: Measure BP on 2+ occasions → Initiate lifestyle changes → Add pharmacologic therapy if persistent

epidemiology: Affects ~10% of adults globally; increasing prevalence due to obesity and sedentary lifestyle.
treatment_protocol: Screen high-risk patients → Confirm diagnosis → Start metformin + lifestyle changes

epidemiology: Affects >650 million adults worldwide. Defined as BMI ≥30 kg/m². Prevalence rising globally.
treatment_protocol: Assess BMI + comorbidities → Lifestyle intervention → Add meds/surgery if no response

epidemiology: Most common acute condition worldwide. Usually viral. Peak incidence in children and during winter.

definitive: Antibiotics only if bacterial cause suspected (e.g., strep throat)

treatment_protocol: Assess symptoms → Supportive care → Antibiotics if red flags for bacterial infection

epidemiology: Lifetime prevalence ~6%; more common in women. Often seen in primary care.
treatment_protocol: Assess via DSM criteria → Start CBT ± SSRIs → Monitor for suicidality

epidemiology: Common in adults, particularly with sedentary lifestyles and Western diets. Often associated with metabolic syndrome.
treatment_protocol: Screen with lipid panel → Assess ASCVD risk → Initiate lifestyle + statin therapy

epidemiology: Affects up to 20% of the population. Common in obesity, pregnancy, and smoking.
treatment_protocol: Empiric PPI → Assess response → Endoscopy if red flags or no improvement

epidemiology: Common in all ages, especially elderly and women. Often functional but may have secondary causes.
treatment_protocol: Lifestyle changes → OTC laxatives → Investigate if refractory or alarm signs

epidemiology: Affects ~10–30% of adults and up to 40% of children. Common trigger includes pollen, dust mites, pet dander.
treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → Start antihistamine/steroid → Consider allergist referral if severe

epidemiology: Most common type of headache. Affects up to 80% of adults at some point.
treatment_protocol: Rule out red flags → Treat with NSAIDs → Preventive meds if frequent

epidemiology: Common in children under 5 years, especially during winter. Linked to viral URTIs and Eustachian tube dysfunction.
treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → Pain control → Antibiotics if severe or <2 years

epidemiology: Common endocrine disorder; more prevalent in women >60 years. Often autoimmune (Hashimoto’s thyroiditis).
treatment_protocol: Check TSH → Confirm with Free T4 → Start levothyroxine, monitor TSH

epidemiology: Affects up to 15% of the global population. More common in women. Often starts in young adulthood.
treatment_protocol: Rule out red flags → Clinical diagnosis → Symptomatic treatment

epidemiology: Common in men >50 years. Affects ~50% by age 60 and up to 90% by age 85.
treatment_protocol: Assess symptoms → PSA + DRE → Start alpha-blockers → Refer if refractory

epidemiology: Common superficial fungal infection. More prevalent in hot, humid climates and contact sports.
treatment_protocol: Confirm via KOH test → Start topical antifungal → Monitor response

epidemiology: Most common nutritional deficiency worldwide. Affects women of reproductive age and children predominantly.

emergency_markers: Hemodynamic instability from acute blood loss

treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Start oral iron → Monitor Hb and ferritin

epidemiology: Affects ~12% of the population; more common in women and onset typically in adolescence or early adulthood.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose clinically → Abortive meds for attacks → Prophylaxis if frequent

epidemiology: Very common in females; 50% of women experience at least one episode. Recurrence is common.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with urinalysis → Empiric antibiotic → Adjust based on culture

epidemiology: Lifetime prevalence ~15%. More common in women and during mid-life. Frequently encountered in primary care.
treatment_protocol: Screen with PHQ-9 → Initiate SSRI/CBT → Monitor and escalate as needed

epidemiology: Most common joint disorder, especially in elderly. Affects weight-bearing joints.
treatment_protocol: Assess clinically + imaging → Conservative measures → Refer if advanced

epidemiology: Affects over 650 million adults worldwide. Major risk factor for diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers.
treatment_protocol: Assess BMI and comorbidities → Lifestyle modification → Meds/surgery if severe

epidemiology: Common dermatological condition affecting 85% of adolescents. May persist into adulthood.

additional: Hormonal panel if signs of hyperandrogenism

treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Start topical agents → Consider oral meds if unresponsive

epidemiology: Affects 1–2% of adults; more common in men and older adults. Strong link with hyperuricemia.

emergency_markers: Severe swelling with fever (rule out septic arthritis)

treatment_protocol: Acute attack: NSAIDs/colchicine → Long-term: urate-lowering therapy

epidemiology: Common superficial fungal infection, especially in humid environments and among athletes.
treatment_protocol: Confirm fungal cause → Apply topical antifungal → Educate on foot care

epidemiology: Less common but life-threatening condition. Defined by severely elevated BP with end-organ damage.

definitive: IV antihypertensives (labetalol, nitroprusside) in ER setting

treatment_protocol: Recognize emergency signs → Transfer to ER → Control BP carefully

epidemiology: Affects up to 30% of adults and 40% of children. Strongly associated with asthma and eczema.
treatment_protocol: Assess clinically → Avoid triggers → Start antihistamines ± steroids

epidemiology: Affects ~20% of Western adults. Risk increases with age, obesity, and smoking.
treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → Lifestyle + PPI trial → Endoscopy if alarm symptoms

epidemiology: Very common; viral causes predominate. Contagious and peaks during outbreaks.
treatment_protocol: Differentiate etiology → Treat symptomatically → Educate on hygiene

epidemiology: Most common cause of heel pain in adults. Frequently seen in runners and obese individuals.
treatment_protocol: Assess clinically → Conservative management → Refer if refractory

epidemiology: Lifetime prevalence ~6%. Often presents in primary care with somatic complaints.
treatment_protocol: Screen with GAD-7 → Start CBT/SSRIs → Monitor progress

epidemiology: Most common cause of vaginal discharge in reproductive-age women. Prevalence up to 29% in the U.S.

emergency_markers: High fever with pelvic pain (suggests PID)

treatment_protocol: Confirm with Amsel criteria → Prescribe metronidazole → Educate on prevention

epidemiology: Affects 4.4% of adults. Risk increases with age, constipation, and pregnancy.

additional: Colonoscopy if bleeding in >50 yrs or atypical features

treatment_protocol: Identify type → Lifestyle mods + topicals → Refer for procedure if recurrent

epidemiology: Common in men >50 years; affects 50% by age 60, up to 90% by age 85.
treatment_protocol: Rule out cancer → Start alpha blocker → Add 5-ARI if large prostate

epidemiology: Affects 0.2–0.4% of the population; more common in women aged 30–50.
treatment_protocol: Rule out other causes → Focus on supportive care → Monitor function

epidemiology: Very common in children; peak incidence between 6 and 18 months. Often follows URI.

emergency_markers: Bulging tympanic membrane with severe pain and high fever

treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → Start antibiotics → Reassess in 48–72 hours if no improvement

epidemiology: Affects 50–60% of women at least once in their lifetime. Common in sexually active women.

additional: Renal ultrasound (if suspect obstruction or recurrent UTI)

treatment_protocol: Diagnose clinically or via urinalysis → Start empiric antibiotics → Culture if necessary

epidemiology: Most common primary headache; affects up to 80% of people at some point.

timeline.symptom: Tightness around forehead or back of head

emergency_markers: First or worst headache (exclude SAH or other causes)

treatment_protocol: Rule out red flags → Start NSAIDs → Preventive meds for frequent episodes

epidemiology: Prevalence is 4–10% in the general population; more common in women and elderly.

emergency_markers: Bradycardia, hypothermia, altered mental status in myxedema coma

treatment_protocol: Check TSH → Start levothyroxine → Monitor response every 6–8 weeks

epidemiology: Most common nutritional disorder worldwide. Affects over 1.6 billion people.

emergency_markers: Severe anemia (Hb <7) with tachycardia or dyspnea

definitive: IV iron if oral not tolerated

treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Start iron therapy → Monitor reticulocyte response

epidemiology: Affects over 200 million people globally. Spread by close contact; outbreaks common in institutions.

additional: Skin scraping for mites, eggs, or feces

treatment_protocol: Apply permethrin → Repeat in 7 days → Prevent reinfestation by hygiene

epidemiology: Affects over 30% of adults globally; a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease.

emergency_markers: Acute coronary syndrome due to plaque rupture

treatment_protocol: Check lipid profile → Assess ASCVD risk → Start statin if indicated

epidemiology: Affects about 12% of the population; more common in women aged 18–44.
treatment_protocol: Assess features → Abortive therapy → Add prophylaxis if frequent

epidemiology: Global prevalence has nearly tripled since 1975. Affects over 650 million adults.
treatment_protocol: Calculate BMI → Lifestyle modification → Consider meds or surgery

epidemiology: Affects ~10–30% of adults worldwide; common in older adults and women.

emergency_markers: Sleep deprivation with suicidal ideation (if comorbid depression)

treatment_protocol: Evaluate sleep pattern → Apply CBT → Use medication short term if needed

epidemiology: Affects up to 20% of children and 3% of adults globally. Often associated with asthma and allergies.
treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Moisturizers + steroids → Escalate if severe

epidemiology: Affects up to 30% of adults and 40% of children globally. Seasonal and perennial forms exist.
treatment_protocol: Assess triggers → Allergen avoidance → Intranasal steroids ± antihistamines

epidemiology: Affects ~20% of adults in Western countries. Chronic condition often requiring long-term management.
treatment_protocol: Start PPI → Assess response → Refer if alarm symptoms

epidemiology: Most common cause of heel pain in adults; peak incidence between ages 40–60.

timeline.symptom: Heel pain with first steps in morning

additional: X-ray to rule out bone pathology

treatment_protocol: Conservative treatment first → Escalate to injections → Rarely surgery

epidemiology: Very common; more frequent in children and highly contagious.

emergency_markers: Visual impairment or severe pain (suggests keratitis)

additional: Gram stain and culture (if recurrent or resistant)

treatment_protocol: Identify typical discharge → Start topical antibiotic → Reassess in 48–72 hours

epidemiology: Prevalence ~10–15% in adults. More common in women, obesity, and pregnancy.

timeline.symptom: Biliary colic (RUQ pain after fatty meal)

emergency_markers: Fever + RUQ pain + jaundice (suggests ascending cholangitis)

treatment_protocol: Ultrasound confirmation → Symptomatic → Elective surgery

epidemiology: Affects 4 in 1,000 people annually; more common in swimmers and humid climates.

emergency_markers: Severe pain with cranial nerve palsy (malignant form)

treatment_protocol: Diagnose clinically → Clean canal → Apply drops → Reassess if no improvement

epidemiology: Common worldwide; affects both children and adults. Spread by contact with infected humans or animals.
treatment_protocol: Topical antifungal for 2–4 weeks → Reassess → Consider oral meds if recurrent

epidemiology: Affects over 1 billion people globally; leading modifiable risk factor for death worldwide.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start lifestyle changes → Add meds based on risk profile

epidemiology: Common in infants, elderly, immunosuppressed, and those using inhaled steroids.

timeline.symptom: White patches on tongue or inner cheeks

treatment_protocol: Identify white plaques → Start topical antifungals → Oral therapy if severe

epidemiology: Common GI complaint; affects 12–19% of general population, more in elderly and women.

emergency_markers: Signs of obstruction (no gas/stool, severe pain)

treatment_protocol: Address lifestyle → Start laxatives → Refer if refractory
